March 19, 2024contribute nowDiscover ‘The Evergreen’ podcastExperience an audio portrait of the Pacific Northwest. Each week, "The Evergreen" podcast tells stories of the people, cultures and lands that make up this place we call home.Listen nowIn The NewsHiking safety Yakona Nature PreserveOregon Rail Heritage CenterDeath doulaQuagga musselsTime capsule from 1955‘The Evergreen’ podcastAlbina Vision Trust‘Salmon Wars’Summer food program Idaho’s first abortion ban takes effectBy James Dawson (Boise State Public Radio News)Aug. 19, 2022 7:37 p.m.The first of Idaho’s slate of abortion bans takes effect today as legal challenges wind their way through the courts.A handful of anti-abortion activists attended a rally organized by Planned Parenthood Saturday, May 14, 2022.James DawsonTHANKS TO OUR SPONSOR:Become a SponsorIdaho Republican legislators passed the law last year, which bans abortions after about six weeks of pregnancy. That’s before many women know they’re pregnant.Doctors who facilitate an abortion after that time could face between two to five years in prison if convicted.THANKS TO OUR SPONSOR:Become a SponsorThe only exceptions are in cases of rape, incest, or “medical emergencies.”It hasn’t taken effect until now because it required a federal appeals court to deem a similar law to be constitutional, which happened in July. That came after the U.S. Supreme Court overturned its decision in the 1973 case Roe v. Wade, which guaranteed a right to abortion in the country.Last Friday, the Idaho Supreme Court declined to temporarily halt these laws while legal challenges to them are ongoing.Family members of a fetus aborted after six weeks can also sue the doctor in civil court for a minimum of $20,000 under a law passed earlier this year.Idaho’s near-total abortion ban takes effect on Aug. 25 barring intervention from a federal judge in a fourth lawsuit. Oral arguments on that motion are set for Monday morning.Follow James Dawson on Twitter @RadioDawson for more local news.This story was originally published by Boise State Public Radio.
